newsitem.title: UK: NWE heating oil premiums steady as freeze persists.
newsitem.headline: NWE heating oil premiums steady as freeze persists.

text.p: Freezing weather gave strong support to NWE heating oil on Friday, but transport problems caused by iced-up canals and pipes curbed buying interest and prevented outright gains in differentials, traders said.
Benchmark Jan and Feb IPE futures shed $4.25 and $3.50 to $227.75 and $222.75 a tonne respectively on bearish U.S. stock data.
Heating oil refinery grade barges traded at Jan IPE +$2.50 for loading on Monday and at Jan IPE +$2 for loading on Tuesday, but material for mid-month went unchanged at +$1.25/+$1.50.
Low sulphur diesel was steady at around Jan IPE +$11/12.
Cargoes saw scattered buying into France and Germany. A 20,000 tonne refinery grade heating oil cargo traded at Feb IPE +$8.25 for Jan 10-20 cif Hamburg, around unchanged.
In cargoes, traders concentrated on trying to obtain heating oil and low sulphur diesel under arbitrage from the U.S. Gulf.
Two 60,000 tonne heating oil vessels were booked from the U.S. Gulf but traders said both had options for a variety of destinations apart from Europe. The arb to Asia remains closed.
A Wall Street trader was rumoured seeking to move Russian low sulphur diesel into Amsterdam.
